body:
Let's take a look at what makes a good entrepreneur and a good idea. 


You'll get to know the key questions to ask yourself about your business ideas, to know if they are any good.


You'll discover:

  • If they are unique
  • If they are right for you
  • If this is the right time to bring them to life!
title: Text Title

body:
Throughout this course and others, we use examples of real-life entrepreneurs to show you how to put some of this advice into practice. Here is a founders Story from Ahmad, the founder of Sellplex.


In this video he shares a portrait of his business.
title: Founder stories: Ahmad at Sellplex

_media._source: C2M2V2 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

displayTitle: Do I have what it takes for a digital business?
body:
Start by tackling the big question: do I have what it takes to start a business?


To be able to answer that, first you need to know that nobody can say for sure if your idea can become a successful business.  If you want to find out, you have to try.


But there are ways to better predict your chances.


Here's how to ask, and answer, the three big questions about any business idea.


Why this idea?

Why me? 

Why now?
title: Do I have what it takes for a digital business?

displayTitle: Give your idea a reality check
body:
Can you decide if your idea is a problem worth solving?


Here's what venture capitalist Vinod Khosla said about problem solving.


'Nobody will pay you for solving a non-problem.'


There are three main reality checks your idea needs to pass.

_items.title: Desirability
_items.body:
Your idea needs to solve a clear need that people have. 


Your first reality check is to find out whether people actually face the problem you are aiming to solve.

You need to have the confidence that you can deliver the solution you imagine. 


Your second reality check is to consider if you can solve the problem people are facing.
_items.title: Feasability
Viability
_items.body:
The cost of solving a problem has to be less than what people will pay you.


Your final reality check is to consider whether you can cover the cost of solving their problems from what you expect to be paid.

title: Giving your idea a reality check

body:
Even if your idea passes the reality check, it’s likely someone else has already had a similar idea.  They are your potential competitors.


For any business to be successful, it needs to do something different to its competitors. That difference is why customers will choose you over them. 


To decide what to do differently, you will need a value proposition. A value proposition is your solution to your customer's problem. 


A good value proposition will say how you solve the problem, and why your solution is the best available.


To help you understand value proposition's better, let's hear from Dave Chapman from UCL's School of Management.
displayTitle: Make sure your idea is distinctive
title: Make sure your idea is distinctive

_media._source: C1M1 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

displayTitle: Founder stories: Sellplex's first attempt at a value proposition
body:
So let's see how a real-life business thinks about a value proposition. In this video, Ahmad, the founder of Sellplex shares with us the value proposition for his business.


How do you think Ahmed's proposition might be improved? We’ll see in another course in this skill how this proposition evolved in response to customer feedback.
title: Founder stories: Sellplex's first attempt at a value proposition

_media._source: C2M2V2 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

displayTitle: Do you have what it takes to be an entrepreneur?
body:
You may have a great idea, but are you the person who should be making it into a business? 


After all, being an entrepreneur isn’t for everyone. So how can you decide if this idea is a good match for you?


 Start-up founders share many key traits. Among the most common are seeking opportunity, taking risks, tolerating failure, creative use of resources and tenacity.


Below you can learn more about each of these key traits.  Think about how many you have.

_items.body:
Seeking opportunity


Entrepreneurs see problems as opportunities. 


They also don't like leaving these opportunities for someone else to pursue.


Do you look at problems in your life, and instantly think about how to solve them?

Risk taking vs security


Entrepreneurs take a risk on a future business rather than looking for a safe job today.


Are you a 'poker player' who is willing to take measured risks to secure future returns?

Tolerating failure


Entrepreneurs fail often but never let that failure deter them.


Do you have the will to experiment and keep going, even if you sometimes fail?

Leveraging resources - creatively 


Entrepreneurs often have to improvise and create solutions with what they have at hand.


Do you have the ability to get what you need from your friends and networks?

Tenacity 


Entrepreneurs regularly have to deal with doubt and uncertainty over their future.


Do you have the persistence to hang in there; to learn from the inevitable setbacks, and drive ideas into action?

title: Do you have what it takes to be an entrepreneur?

body:
Successful businesses can spot when a change creates new opportunities. 


Nokia was originally a paper mill, Sony sold radios, and Mitel made lawnmowers. 


These businesses saw societal and technological change and identified an opportunity to succeed.


For your idea to be successful, you will need to think carefully about how you can identify a change. 


What has changed, or is changing, that will influence people to buy from you? 


It might be that you offer a brand new technology, you can solve a new problem, or make something more affordable and practical.


Whatever the change, you need to be clear on how the world today will contribute to making your business a success. 


Having a clear answer to this question will certainly boost your odds.
title: Is your timing right?

body: Collect 50 points for every correct answer
title: Text Title

body: Of the six options below, which three criteria would you use to give your new business idea a reality check?

These are the essential reality checks for any new idea.


Desirability - does anyone need it?

Feasibility - can we do it?

Viability - do we have the resources to make it work?

That’s right!


Desirability (does anyone need it), feasibility (can we do it), and viability (do we have the resources to make it work), are the essential reality checks for any new idea.

But how would you define the idea if someone asked you?

_incorrect.final:

body:
While every entrepreneur is different, many share a set of common traits. 


Match the traits to the opportunities.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


These are some of the common traits.


  • You look at problems and see solutions
  • You are willing to take a risk for a future return
  • You can improvise solutions where none exist
  • You move on quickly from your mistakes

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


These are some of the common traits.

 

  • You look at problems and see solutions
  • You are willing to take a risk for a future return
  • You can improvise solutions where none exist
  • You move on quickly from your mistakes

title: T1C1Q3 Take a look in the mirror

body:
When considering if your idea has what it takes to become a business, we recommend you consider the foundations on which your business is built.


Why this idea ?

Why me ?

Why now ?


Once you've considered those questions ask yourself: what next ?
title: You have what it takes!

body:
Setting up a business usually means pouring your heart and soul into it. 


That's why it is so important for you to really believe in your idea and to have good reason to believe it will work. 


Let's take a look at some key business techniques to: 

  • Generate new ideas 
  • Evaluate your ideas against your own strengths
title: Text Title

displayTitle: How can I come up with new ideas?
body:
Let's start by looking at how you can better manage your business ideas. 


Generating ideas, then refining them, is a discipline which successful entrepreneurs practise regularly. 


Learning how to manage your ideas process will help you make the most of your time.
title: How can I come up with new ideas?

body:
Making an idea into reality needs energy and commitment. 


To keep this energy going, even when things get tough, you need to love what you’re doing. 


Look carefully at your ideas to understand what turns you on about this specific opportunity.


Passion is infectious. If you really care about your idea, it will make it much easier to convince your first customers, and your partners, why they should feel the passion too.
title: Staying interested

displayTitle: How to find ideas you are passionate about
body:
We know that we need ideas we care deeply about, to be able to turn them into good businesses.


So what strategies can we use to find these ideas? 


Neil Lurie, an expert on idea creation, suggests in his handbook that there are four ways to find ideas you are passionate about.

_items.title: Doing what you love
_items.body:
What do you enjoy doing in your own time? 


If something interests you in life, chances are it will interest you as a business.

Do you face a regular frustration for which you can’t find a solution? 


Many successful ideas come for entrepreneurs creating solutions to problems that are personal to them.
_items.title: Solving your own problem
Using your expertise
_items.body:
Are you an expert in something?


Your edge in understanding might be a great source of new ideas.

_items.title: Borrowing from another community
_items.body:
Have you seen a good idea somewhere else? 


Often we will come across good ideas in another country or sector.

title: How to find ideas you are passionate about

displayTitle: Four questions to make sure an idea for you
body:
Even the best idea might not work work for you. 


A useful way of checking whether it is the right idea is to answer the following four questions:


  1. Is it doable? If not, nothing else matters!
  2. Can I do it? You need confidence you are the right person.
  3. Is it worth doing? The rewards of doing it have to be worth the effort.
  4. Do I want to do it? Because if not, why force yourself?


If you can't answer 'yes' to those questions, it might be time to rethink your idea.
title: Four questions to make sure an idea for you

body: Here are the founders of The Sports Review, Audio3 and BioBean about how they identified opportunities and brought them to reality.

_completion.completeText: So BioBean decided to recycle a business idea from another community. Another great strategy.

_items.question: So sports review decided to do what they love!
The founder of sound cube couldn't find a solution to his problem on the market so he created one.
_items.optionText: Click here to hear from the next founder!
Click here to hear from the final founder!

title: Let's hear from some founders

body: Collect 50 points for every correct answer
title: Text Title

body:

Which of the following is one of them?

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Creating a solution to a problem you have experience of is a great way to find an idea that sparks your passion.


If you can empathise with the problem, you are much more likely to have the passion to create a solution!
_incorrect.final:

title: T1C2Q1 Find ideas you love

body:
To test if your idea is the right one for you, there are four questions you should be able to answer 'yes' to.


Can you select all four?

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


If an idea is right for you, you should be able to answer yes to the following questions:


Is it doable? Can I do it? Is it worth doing? and last but not least Do I want to do it?
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


If an idea is right for you, you should be able to answer yes to the following questions:


Is it doable? Can I do it? Is it worth doing? and last but not least Do I want to do it?

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


If an idea is right for you, you should be able to answer yes to the following questions:


Is it doable? Can I do it? Is it worth doing? and last but not least Do I want to do it?

_feedback.correct:
That’s Right!


If an idea is right for you, you should be able to answer yes to the following questions:


Is it doable? Can I do it? Is it worth doing? and last but not least Do I want to do it?

_items.text: Will it look good on my resume?
Am I going to strike it rich?
Will my parents be proud of me?
Do I want to do it?

title: T1C2Q2 Asking yourself the tough questions

body:
Arthur Kay and Benjamin Harriman, founders of BioBean, turn coffee ground waste into biofuels into the UK.


But which of Lurie's four strategies did they use to come up with their idea?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Arthur and Benjamin used established biofuel technology to transform coffee ground waste into biofuels into the UK.
_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Arthur and Benjamin used established biofuel technology to transform coffee ground waste into biofuels into the UK.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


Arthur and Benjamin used established biofuel technology to transform coffee ground waste into biofuels into the UK.

title: T1C2Q3 How BioBean chose their idea

body:
Developing and refining your ideas is a really important discipline for entrepreneurs. 


By practising the approaches we've covered, you can quickly improve your thinking and decide which ideas to pursue.
title: b

body:
If you think you have found a good idea, you need to start fleshing out the details. There are many popular methods to do this.


Let's look at:


  • Approaches to refining your business idea
  • Testing your idea on potential customers 
  • The techniques for building a business model around your idea
title: Test your ideas

body:
Very few successful business ideas are born fully-formed. 


Your understanding of what customers need and your ideas for solutions will evolve as your business grows. This process of learning something new about the world, then changing your thinking, is at the centre of what entrepreneurs do.


Tom Kelly, the founder of IDEO, provides us with a five-step process for idea refinement.

_items.body:
Develop your understanding


Get a grip on the market, the target audience, the technology and the problem. Understand them as deeply as you can.

Observe real people in real situations


Check your understanding against ordinary people. 


Find out what makes them tick, what confuses them, what they like, what they hate, and how they feel about things.

Visualise the idea


Bring your ideas to life visually, so that others can see and understand what’s in your head.

Prototype rapidly


Quickly build, test, and discard a series of working models. Figure out what works for people, what doesn’t, and what confuses them.

Implement your idea


Bring the new idea to market rapidly. Then go back to developing your understanding.

title: How to refine your ideas

body:
Your new business may appeal to everyone but, as a new startup, your resources will be very limited. So it’s important to be specific about your customers. This will help you design an even better business model.


But how should you split customers into target areas?


Here are three different ways to help you divide your customers more precisely.

_items.backText:
Demographics
This approach segments customers by their background. You might use age, income or location. 
This approach helps you target customer channels and activities.

Behaviour
This approach segments customers based on how they will interact with your business. Think membership tiers, frequency of use or amount of money spent. 
This approach helps you target your customer relationships and revenue.

Needs
Using this approach you can segment customers by what problem they want to solve. You might use their daily lives or their long-term goals as a guide. 
This approach helps you target value proposition and partnerships.

title: Nail your customer profiles

body:
Developing and testing your ideas is an essential skill for any entrepreneur. 


Thankfully, there is a framework to help you. It’s called effectual entrepreneurship.


The framework is a series of steps as you start your business. 


The steps are at at regular intervals. As you follow the steps, you can update your business model canvas to keep track of each iteration.


This helps to highlight critical uncertainties and risks that you should try to address.
displayTitle: Testing your ideas in the real world
title: Testing your ideas in the real world

_media._source: C1M2 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

displayTitle: Turn your idea into a business model
body:
The process of turning an idea into a business requires us to be pragmatic in our approach.


We need to consider things like:


  • What we will do
  • Who will be our customers 
  • How will we make money


The way we answer these questions is to create a business model.


In simple terms, a business model sets out what our business plans to do, who for, and how we will make money from it.


The Financial Times defines a business model as:


'The method or means by which a company tries to capture value from its business.'


Your business model will guide every action your business takes, from producing a product or service, to sales and marketing.
title: Turn your idea into a business model

body:
To develop a business model for your idea, we recommend using a tool called the Business Model Canvas. 


The Canvas is a simple and popular way of organising all your ideas about a business.


Good business ideas need to be desirable, feasible and viable, and the business model canvas helps us to dig deeper into those criteria, helping us to think about the logic of how our business will work.
title: Organise your thoughts

_media._source: C1M3 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: The Business Model Canvas has nine elements, similar to what was shown in the video.

_items.title: Customers
_items.body:
These are the people you want to reach in your business. 


They are the ones who are going to buy from you and whose lives you hope to improve.

This is your solution to your customer’s problem. 


Whoever you are selling to, this is your explanation for why they should buy from you.
_items.title: Value proposition
Channels
_items.body: This describes how customers will learn about your business, how they will buy from you and how you will deliver your solutions to them.

_items.title: Relationships
_items.body:
This describes what kind of relationship you are going to have with customers and clients. 


Are you providing something they can’t live without, or something they only buy once?
This looks at all the ways you will make money from your customers.
_items.title: Revenue

_items.body:
This describes the main things you will be doing in your business. 


They might be day-to-day or unique.
_items.title: Activities
Resources
_items.body: These are the things you will need to be in business, including your products, your team, and anything else important to you.

_items.title: Partnerships
_items.body:
These are the people who will help your business succeed. 


Think about whose help you might need.

_items.title: Costs
_items.body: This looks at how much it will cost to run the business.

_incomplete.label: Click on the options below to explore the Canvas.

title: Explore the Canvas

body:
Here is a founders Story from Ahmad, the founder of Sellplex.


Ahmad is talking UCL's Dr. Dave Chapman through his business model canvas.
title: Founder stories: Ahmad at Sellplex

_media._source: C2M2V2 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
Now you know how to create a Business Model Canvas. 


Business modelling is a question of practise and there is no limit to the number of business models you can create.


It's a good idea to complete a few trial canvases before turning your attention to your own idea.


Try building a canvas using a business you know well or one where you are a customer. It's a great way to get to understand that business even better.


You can create a canvas by hand using pen and Post-It Notes, or try these free, online versions.


Show me - Canvanizer


Show me - BM|DESIGN|ER
title: Hone your business model skills

Clearly, you know your customer segments from your cost structure. 


You're well on the way to becoming a business modelling Pro.

This is your solution to your customer’s problem

title: T1C3Q2 Got a grip on canvas?

displayTitle: Create your own business model canvas
body: Now you know how important a business model can be, when do you think you should create a business model canvas for your company?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


There's no limit to the number of canvases you can create. Things change and your business model may need to change too. Make a new canvas any time you have a significant change in your business.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


There is no limit to the number of canvases you can create.


Things change and your business model may need to change too. Make a new canvas any time you have a significant change in your business.

_items.text: When we first start out.  After that it will be smooth sailing!
After a few years.  We can figure it out once we've been in business for a while.
If an investor asks for one.  Not much point otherwise.
Whenever we see a change in our business.  We will create one and then keep it updated.

title: T1C3Q3 Create your own business model canvas

body:
Now you've learnt how to create a business model around your new idea. 


The canvas is a really useful tool for helping you think about what's important in your business. 


Keep practising building business model canvases and it will save you time and effort in the long run.
title: Testing your ideas. Let's wrap it up

body:
When planning a business, we are always making assumptions about what our customers really want. 


The best way to make sure you are not barking up the wrong tree is to speak to your customers as soon as possible.


Let's have a look at how to:

  • Find customers to speak to in the first place
  • Ask customers the right questions so they tell you what they think rather than what they think you want to hear
  • Use their feedback to refine your idea (or decide to follow another one!)
title: Text Title

body:
Many entrepreneurs trip themselves up when talking to customers.


We often fail to ask good questions, which means we don’t get good answers. What we need is a structure to help us get the most from our conversations with customers. 


A good way to structure your questions is by using Rob Fitzpatrick’s ‘Mom Test’. 


Show me - The Mom Test


The three 'Mom Test' principles will help you ask better questions:

  • Talk about your customer's life instead of your idea
  • Ask about specifics in the past instead of opinions about the future
  • Talk less and listen more
title: Give your conversations structure

_media._source: C1M5 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

displayTitle: Founder stories: Sellplex on talking to customers
body:
Here is a founder story from Ahmad, the founder of Sellplex.


Ahmad is talking through his approach to customer conversations and how to overcome some of the challenges entrepreneurs face.
title: Founder stories: Sellplex on talking to customers

_media._source: C2M2V2 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
Using the Mom Test as a guide, we now need to build a script for our interviews. 


The script will have all the main questions you plan to ask. It's really useful for keeping you to time as well.


While there are lots of ways you can create a script, we recommend using the following structure from Ash Maurya’s Running Lean.


Show me - Running Lean

_items.body:
Hi, my name is...


A few brief introductory and biographical questions to put the customer at ease


Example - Can you tell me a little bit about your business?

What's the problem?


Two or three questions about when the person might have faced the problem your idea solves. Ask about occasions when they face that problem and how that problem affects them.


Example - 'Tell me about the last time you ... and when this occurs, how much additional time or money does it cost you?’

Tell me more...


These are dig deeper questions to keep your interviewee talking about the problem.


Example - When this occurs, how much additional time or money does it cost your company?

Can I call you?


These bring the interview to a close and let the person know how they can stay involved with your work.


Example - Would you be willing to help us by participating in some user research?

Treasured memories


Not a part of the interview but something to do straight away. Write down your results as soon as possible. 


You don’t want to forget important things by waiting until later.

title: Ask the right questions

displayTitle: Who should I be talking to?
body:
Even with a great script, you still need to talk to the right people. 


In the universe of possible customers for your product or service, some are more useful than others. 


Steve Blank tells you what to look for, starting from the least valuable to the most valuable:

  • Those who have the problem - but are not aware of the fact. It doesn't trouble them in getting their jobs done.
  • Those who are aware of the problem - but view it as a low level nuisance or irritation that is not worth expending energy to resolve.
  • Those who have been actively seeking a solution
  • Those who have taken some action to patch together at least some parts of a solution
  • Those who, in addition, have or can acquire a budget
title: Who should I be talking to?

body:
Even if you know how to get the most from your customer conversations, how do you know where they are located? 


Finding customers usually requires you to search through several sources.

_items.body:
Friends & family


Even if your close family and friends can't help, you’ll often find someone in their networks who fits your target customer profile. 


Use referrals from people you know to reach those you want to speak to.

Social networking


Networks like Facebook and Twitter can help you reach people fast. 


However, if you drown people in requests, they will quickly start ignoring you. Reach out to specific people for a better result.

Communities

Places like meetup.com are great sources for finding groups of target customers. 


Be aware, though, that these communities can be close-knit and not always receptive to outsiders straight away. You will need to build up trust before you reach out to them with your idea.

Professional networks 


Online professional tools like LinkedIn can be a quick way to find people who fit the bill. 


You can look for individuals in specific roles or organisations and plot a route to reach them using shared connections.

Publishing content


What about creating a blog to get interested parties to come to you? 


This provides an opportunity to establish you as a voice and someone people will tune in to. Keep your content fresh otherwise users won’t return.

Online research


Q&A sites like Quora can help you tap into a community to find potential customers. 


If you can provide high quality insights related to your business area then you can build a following.

_incomplete.label: Click on the options below to explore.

title: Find your customers

body:
Once you have feedback from your customers, you need to decide what to do with it. 


What do we do when customers are telling you something that contradicts your thinking? When customer feedback doesn’t line up with your idea, you have three options:

  • Keep going. If you keep going, you run the risk that your customers won’t value what you offer. So in most cases, you should avoid this option.
  • Back to the drawing board. You may decide that this idea just doesn’t work for people. That’s okay. Better to discard it now than invest in something people don’t value.
  • Pivot. You may decide that what customers are telling you gives you a different way to solve their problem. If you decide to pursue that new version of the idea, this is called pivoting.
title: Act on your feedback

_incorrect.body: Incorrect answer, click continue to try again
_incorrect.title: Incorrect

displayTitle: Founder stories: Sellplex on refining your value proposition
body:
Conversations with customers can give you valuable information on how to present your business. In this video, Ahmed shows us how he changed his value proposition on the basis of talking to customers. 


First, you'll see his value proposition before talking to customers. Then the updated version based on what he learned.
title: Founder stories: Sellplex on refining your value proposition

body:
Rob Fitzpatrick's  Mom Test is a good way to make sure your customer conversations stay on track. 


What are the three principles of The Mom Test?

The three principles of the 'Mom Test' are to talk about their life instead of your idea, ask them about past specifics topics and problems instead of future opinions and talk less and listen more.

Keep the conversation going at all costs, don't be afraid to tell lies and always promote yourself!
Try to look bored with their answers, don't give away your secrets and attempt to talk them out of buying.

title: T1C4Q2 Find your customers

body:
There are three ways you can respond to negative feedback. 


You could carry on, go back to the drawing board or change course. 


But what is that change of course called in startup-speak?

_feedback.correct:
That's Right!


When you decide that what customers are telling you gives you a different way to solve their problem and pursue that new version of the idea, it is called ‘pivoting’.

_incorrect.final:

When you decide that what customers are telling you gives you a different way to solve their problem and pursue that new version of the idea, it is called ‘pivoting’.

title: T1C4Q3 Make feedback count

body:
Now you have the tools to go out and hold great customer conversations.


By applying the Mom Test and scripting your questions in advance, you can make sure you get the most from every conversation with your potential customers.
title: keep clear

body:
So you've got a good idea and you have spoken to potential customers who feel your solution solves their problem. And you believe that your business model is sound.


If your business is to succeed, at some point those ideas need to become products.


So how do you go about bringing your product to life? 


The leap from idea to product can be daunting for any business. To help you think it through, we will introduce some Lean Startup techniques to simplify the stages.


Let's see how to:

  • Discover all about Lean Startup
  • Develop hypotheses you would like to test early on
  • Prioritise what you would like to start with
title: Text Title

body:
The Lean Startup is an approach to running a new business. 


Lean Startups begin with the idea that nobody gets anything right the first time. The key to nailing your business is to learn from your mistakes and improve your products quickly.


Lean Startups focus on three things:

  • Building the simplest solution you can to the problem, known as a minimum viable product (MVP)
  • Measuring that solution with potential customers and gathering as much feedback as you can about how it works
  • Learning lessons from what you have done to improve your thinking with the next MVP
title: What is The Lean Startup?

body: Video credit: LaunchSpark Video
title: Video Stream Title

body:
The Lean Startup process always starts with a hypothesis. 


This hypothesis is your best guess about how customers will respond to your product. This guess is what will shape the MVP you build, the test results you receive, and ultimately the ideas you come up with.


It's important that your hypothesis follows a specific structure. After all, you want to get the best possible results.

_items.body:
The structure


We believe that [this capability or feature of the product] will result in [this outcome].


We will know our hypothesis is true when [specific signal from customers] happens.

Example


Take an example from Ash Maurya.He says that if people believe he is an expert, they will be more likely to use his product.


For example:

I believe that being known as an expert will drive early adopters.


I will know this to be true when I make a blog post, it drives more than 100 early sign ups.

title: Develop your hypothesis

body:
Using Lean Startup, you can start creating a to-do list for your new business idea. 


You are likely to have a lot of things you want to do, probably more than you have time for. How can you decide in what order to do things?


To help you make sure your time is being spent wisely, it makes sense to prioritise a queue of work. 


The order of any item in the queue can be set by considering how big a risk it would be to not prioritise it.

_items.title: List your risks
_items.body:
Your new startup will face three main categories of risk:

  • Product risks: getting the product right
  • Customer risks: building a path to the customer
  • Market risk: building a viable business

Next, give each risk a score from 1 (lowest) to 5 (highest) for both of the following:

  • How likely is this risk to actually happen?
  • How damaging would it be if nothing was done about it?
_items.title: Estimate the likelihood

_items.body:
Identify when each risk is likely to occur. 


Some risks might happen very quickly, while others won't be a problem for a while.


Use these helpful time-frames:

  • Risks you will face in creating your solution
  • Risks you will face in rolling out your solution to customers
  • Risks you will face in growing your business
_items.title: Group by timing

_items.body:
Finally, rank the risks in each time-frame based on their combined likelihood and impact scores. 


You now have a priority order for your actions!
_items.title: Rank them

title: Set your priorities

body:
As you move through the cycle of build, measure, learn, it is important to keep track of the insights you gather and the changes you make. 


To track their progress, many entrepreneurs use a canvas. The most popular canvas is the Business Model Canvas (BMC). You can learn more about the BMC in our course 'How entrepreneurs test and refine their ideas'.


Some entrepreneurs consider the BMC too much detail. A growing number now prefer the 'Lean Canvas'. Whichever one you choose, using a canvas will help you track changes to your product and make your next step clearer.


To learn more about the Lean Canvas and Business Model Canvas, click the link below.


SHOW ME: Lean Canvas vs. Business Model Canvas
displayTitle: Using a canvas to track your progress
title: Using a canvas to track your progress

body: Collect 50 points for every correct answer

body:

What is this statement called?

title: T1C5Q2 Get Lean!

Place the following items into their rank order, from 1 to 4.

_incorrect.notFinal:

cancelButtonAriaLabel: This button cancels the current selected option
title: T1C5Q3 Rank your risks

body:
Now you've discovered the foundations of turning your idea into your product. 


If you stick to The Lean Startup process, stay on top of your risks and prioritise your work, then you can develop rapid, effective prototypes.


The Lean Startup process will ensure that your idea will get off the ground and into your customers' business.
title: From idea to product - the Lean Startup way

body:
With your business and business model in mind, the next step is to find out what already exists in the market to solve your customer's problems.


To do this:

  • Find other businesses with the same ideas 
  • Work out what size and shape your market is 
  • Identify what will make you better than your competitors
title: Text Title

body:
So far, developing your business model has required you to focus on yourself - learning how to assess whether your idea has the potential to become a business and how to plan for the future using the business model canvas.


The next step requires you to turn your attention outside of your business to look at the market your business is entering, and the competition it is likely to face.


Let's start by watching Ahmed, founder of Sellplex, talk UCL's Dave Chapman through how he is positioning himself to succeed.
title: Who else has similar ideas?

_media._source: video3-dave and ahmad 6 (1) from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
The business model canvas helps us think through a new business concept. 


However, to fully explore our new business idea, we need to consider other factors. 


Most of the factors we need to consider relate to the market in which your business will operate.

_items.body:
Market size is a measure of the number of people who are potential buyers of what you sell. 


If you think of your business as competing for a slice of the pie, then market size measures how big that pie is.
_items.title: Market size
Trends & drivers
_items.body:
Market trends - patterns in the behaviour of companies working on a particular problem. For example, mass moves toward a new technology or business model. 


Market drivers - any factor that causes a change in the market. For example, a change in what people are buying or a change in government regulations.

Competition refers to the other companies who solve similar problems to your business. 


Competitors can be:

Direct - they offer a product or service which is essentially the same as yours 

Indirect - they offer a different product or service that could be used to solve the same problem.
_items.title: Competitiors
Team
_items.body:
Every business has at least one founder. 


You will also, as you grow, be joined by some key people who take a big role in what you create and how you operate. 


How your team views the future, and what skills they bring are essential considerations for the future.

title: Understand your market

body:
Thinking through your market can be daunting. 


To help make it easier for you, take a look at a new tool called the New Business Road Test developed by John Mullins.


Show me - The New Business Road Test


It's there to help you consider how big an opportunity your business represents as well as how your competitors are likely to respond.


John Mullins introduces you to the New Business Road Test to get you comfortable with the key terms and concepts.
title: Think through your market

_media._source: C1M4 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
Understanding the size of your market requires us to make three educated guesses:


  • How many people might need your products?
  • How many of them do you expect to buy from you? 
  • How much, on average, will your buyers spend?

_items.title: Number of potential buyers
_items.body:
To calculate the number of potential buyers, you need to find data on how many people exist that might face the problem you solve. 


Then divide that number by how many of those people you are ‘going after’. This number is your total potential buyers.


For example, there might be three million people in the UK who want a better bank account. Of these, we might be targeting only those under 35, and living in cities. Let’s say there are 200,000 all up. 


Those 200,000 people are your potential buyers.

To calculate how many of your potential buyers will end up buying what you offer, we need to understand how many customers other people in this market share. 


To do this we use ‘market share’, which is the % of potential customers using each service. We then estimate how many customers of others could end up buying from us instead.


For example, let's say that of our 200,000 potential customers, they are evenly split between the five big banks (Barclays, HSBC, Lloyds, RBS and Santander). 


This means each bank has a 20% share of our market and we have none. Now let’s assume that our service can tempt 2000 customers of each bank to switch. 


This would set our expected market share at 5%, or 10,000 people.
_items.title: Expected market share
Average spend per customer
_items.body:
To calculate how much our buyers will end up spending, we need to estimate the average spend per customer. 


We do this by using the average cost of our products and multiply this by how often the average person will buy. We then multiply this figure by our expected market share.


For example, let's say our new bank has a average fee of £3 per month for an account. This means our average customer will spend £36 per year. 


That means our expected return for the business is £36 multiplied by the 10,000 customers we expect will buy from us, which equals -  £ 360,000.

title: Examine you market

displayTitle: Consider what is driving your market

_items.body:
Outside of our own business, we need to look at how circumstances in the wider world will affect our business. 


For example, maybe new legislation will make it harder for us to work. Or perhaps the number of potential customers for our products is growing as populations expand.


Whatever is coming your way in the future, it pays to be prepared. 


A handy business tool you can use is PEST - political, economic, social and technological drivers of change.


It will help you cover the big questions about what might change for your business.


Show me - PEST analysis

title: Consider what is driving your market

body:
If you have identified a great opportunity in the market, then it is also likely that you are not the only one.


You will undoubtedly face competition from either other established businesses who currently have your potential customers, or from other newcomers to the market looking to tempt those same customers, too.


To give yourself the best chance of winning those customers, you will need to have the edge over the competition. 


But how can we decide what gives you the edge? 


For something to be the competitive edge, it needs four qualities, collectively known as VRIO.

_items.title: Valuable
_items.body:
The first test is whether your potential customers value what you offer. 


If they don’t find what you do valuable, they aren’t likely to pay for it and you will be at a disadvantage.

The second test is to determine what you have is rare.


If only a very few people have what you have, it is more likely that potential customers will have to choose you if they find what you have valuable.
_items.title: Rare

_items.body:
The third test is how difficult your solution would be for a competitor to copy.


The greater the difficulty for a newcomer to copy what you have produced, the higher the ultimate value.
_items.title: Difficult to Imitate
Organised to deliver value
_items.body:
The final test is whether your business is set up to capture the value coming from what you offer. 


Even a business with a better idea will be out competed if it doesn’t make the most of it’s advantages. 


You will be better able to maintain your edge if you can streamline the way your business operates.

title: Identify your competitive edge

body:
Your team is going to be the driving force behind your success. 


However, even the best teams can become ineffective if they are not in sync.


John Mullins devotes three of his seven domain models to consideration of the team. 


Consider the following tests and think about how your team measures up.

_items.body:
Well connected within the value chain


The reputation of your team is important. 


Often, in the early days of your business, the personal relationships of your team can be key to success. 


Consider the following:

  • Has your team developed deep customer insights into your chosen market?
  • Have they built up a following in the industry?
  • Will they be able to open doors for you?

Able to execute on critical success factors


You will need to rely on your team to help the business succeed. 


Consider the following:

  • Does the team realistically deliver the key capabilities critical to business success?
  • Does their work reflect the standards and values you hope for in the business?
  • Does your team have the necessary skills to deliver?

Share a common mission and a shared appetite for risk


As your business grows, it's important that you and your team all share an understanding of where you want the organisation to go. 


Consider the following:

  • Is your team committed to the same vision for the future?
  • Is your appetite for risk the same as your teams?
  • If one of you is struggling financially while another is well off, it can cause serious tensions.

title: Build a winning team

_items.body:
Once you have captured your market share, what do you do now? Relax, and eat your ‘slice of the pie’?  Well, not exactly. 


Most startups ultimately aim to grow and expand beyond their initial customers.  


In 1957, Igor Ansoff, the father of Strategic Management, explained that business expansion can happen in four ways:

  • Penetration. You get a larger percentage of the potential customers in your market.
  • Products. You introduce new things to increase the average spend.
  • Markets. You find more people by expanding into a new country or customer type.
  • Diversification. You build a different thing for a different market (not recommended!).


You need to think carefully about the potential these may bring to your business in the future.

body: Collect 50 points for every correct answer
title: Text Title

body:
We know that when we estimate the size of the market we need to do several different calculations. 


But what order should we make them in?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


When calculating the size of the market, we should start with the number of people who fit the target audience, then how many of them we expect to buy from us, and finally how much each of them will spend with us on average.
_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


When calculating the size of the market, we should start with the number of people who fit the target audience, then how many of them we expect to buy from us, and finally how much each of them will spend with us on average.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


When calculating the size of the market, we should start with the number of people who fit the target audience, then how many of them we expect to buy from us, and finally how much each of them will spend with us on average.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


When calculating the size of the market, we should start with the number of people who fit the target audience, then how many of them we expect to buy from us, and finally how much each of them will spend on average.

title: T1C6Q1 Measure up the market

displayTitle: Assess the strengths of your team
body:

Which of the following is one of those simple checks?

_incorrect.final:

Your team's connections into the value chain of your market is an important check you should perform in starting a business.


Where they live, their office design skills, and their political opinions might make things easier, but they aren't key to success.

Are you sure about that?


Your team's connections into the value chain of your market is an important check you should perform in starting a business.


Where they live, their office design skills, and their political opinions might make things easier, but they aren't key to success.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


Your team's connections into the value chain of your market is an important check you should perform in starting a business. 


Where they live, their office design skills, and their political opinions might make things easier, but they aren't key to success.

_items.text: Is my team able to execute on critical success factors?
Does my team all live in the same neighbourhood?
Does my team understand how to lay out an office?
Does my team agree with me on politics?

title: T1C6Q2 Assess the strengths of your team

body:
When we think about how a new business might develop in the future, there are a number of different strategies that can be used.


One of these strategies is to find more people by expanding into a new country or customer type.


But which of Igor Ansoff's means of expansion does this describe?
instruction: Choose the answer that best matches the description.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Pursuing a market expansion strategy is where you take the same product to a new country or type of customer.
_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Pursuing a market expansion strategy is where you take the same product to a new country or type of customer.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Pursuing a market expansion strategy is where you take the same product to a new country or type of customer.

_feedback.correct:
That's Right!


Pursuing a market expansion strategy is where you take the same product to a new country or type of customer.

title: T1C6Q3 Think about your future strategy

body:
Now you know how to assess the market for your new business venture. 


You will find that the road test is a great companion to the business model canvas.
title: Get a handle on your market!
